No one's been able to identify what is "toxic" in that log.  A couple have speculated that I was being negative to my team, but they were wrong about what was said to whom.  DTN just said that everything, literally _everything_ I wrote, was toxic, which is absurd and obviously grasping at straws.  See for yourself.  I don't even cuss.

Taunting a player for being in silver, repeatedly: "400 games in silver say otherwise" and "I can see you're upset about the 400 games, huh?"
More taunting: "blaming region, that's funny"
Taunting your jungler: "Never seen a shaco lose jg to a lee sin before..."
Ganging up on the 2 people you have been harassing: "Alistar is shaco's waifu", "Funny"
Passive aggressiveness towards others: "Ali stop being toxic pls", "Don't forget to honor me for not getting tilted from all the negativity my team directed towards me ;)"
More taunting: "So mad"

And then the famous "gg ez"

You were trying to illicit a reaction through taunting and being passive aggressive.

All of this would have likely been a chat restriction if it was a consistent behavior. However, this was far from your first offense and as such it was escalated to the next level of punishment. Which in your case was a perma-ban .. the day after you got back from a 14-day ban.

In fact, I was not taunting that player.  I was defending myself because they were telling me how much better than me they were.  Ditto the "blaming region" thing, because a player was saying everyone on NA was garbage.  The comment to the shaco was actually the exact thing he said to me in the same game, about my losing vs my top lane counterpart.  So, on all these counts, you're mistaken.

It's also very strange to hear you say that asking someone to stop being toxic when they were constantly flaming me, and priding one's self on still trying their hardest when they were losing badly up til the late game, is passive aggressive.  Or that I alone am, somehow, "ganging up" on someone.  And as I said before, the "gg ez" was ironic.  It was far from it.

Your take on this is patently like tea leaf reading.  Not through any fault of your own, of course.  This is simply a problem with the report system.  There's no context, no one else's comments, no scores to be seen, all unlike the Tribunal.  I do appreciate that you mentioned that this happened the day after I returned.  Time and again, Lyte and other Riot employees have mentioned that every player is occasionally "toxic", that they have a bad game and say harsh things.  This is one game after a 14 day downtime.  There's literally no chance for a pattern to be established.  And all told, there's very little "toxicity" to it.

These reasons are why I feel this ban is invalid and unfair.  I should have been given some time to prove myself, one way or another.  This one game actually demonstrates nothing.  I'm actually an extremely positive and friendly player, but I'm gregarious, and my words are always _always_ taken in the worst light possible, as you've shown here.

If you really wanted to defend yourself, you would have muted and reported, since that's kinda the perfect way to do that.
If you feel the need to reply, you're not really trying to defend yourself, you're trying to defend your pride and your ego in front of random people on the internet... That's just my general advice. Advice I hardly follow myself.

But here's the thing: There's "pure" self defense, and there's retaliation. You "defended yourself" by attacking the person that flamed you. And that has been clarified often enough to be punishable behaviour.

I appreciate what you're saying about remaining silent, and it's something I have been doing, and will continue to do in the future.  I just think it's absurd that I am being banned because of a single game, as that is all that is included in that report, and indeed, I had only played a handful of games since returning to that account, especially because that game is so...mild.  There's absolutely no "you suck" or other insults, no cursing.  Most of what is said is self-deprecating, and even grateful to other players (I thanked Kallista for not joining in the flame brigade).  

I should actually be given an opportunity to demonstrate that I am reformed, rather than have my account taken from me immediately upon returning to the game.  I can only help but feel that this is nothing more than an attempt by Riot to separate me from my money.
I usually join in on the rioters smiting people on this but I honestly don't think that you were that toxic there
Thank you for being brave enough to say so.

Not speaking for riot, but think of the analogy the boy who cried wolf. 
If you just keep reporting people all the time (without just cause), eventually the ones who truly deserve it will fall through the cracks.
Especially if Riots reporting system devalue's your reports due to  "spam".

Yes, that's exactly my point though. 
If the system devalues someone's report due to "spam", doesn't that hurt the community more? People who truly deserve it will be able to get off from being reported just because someone with a reduced report weight reported them.

Sure the boy who cried wolf is a legit argument, and in no way do I mean to imply that it's okay to spam reports, but I believe reducing someone's weight does more harm than good overall.

At the end of the day, if you "fake" report someone, nothing bad will happen to the player reported. 
So what's the point in having the system devalue players' reports?

I found a really old post of Rioter Lyte (I think it was him) where the main argument in having playes' report weight reduced was that report calling and fake reporting could be used to bully people during the game which in turn would be creating a negative atmosphere. 

EDIT: I can try and find it again but I've stumbled across it quite some time ago so not sure if I can find the link again.

However I believe reducing a player's report weight will not solve this. 
If I were a "toxic" player I could easily still ask people to report you, or threaten you with a possible report at end game, etc. 
In other words, the negative aspect of fake reporting and spam reporting doesn't change in either case, don't you agree?

Was just wondering if a Rioter could try to help me understand the issue more, as I could be missing something in my chain of thought.

Note: I'm not working for Riot, so I don't know the exact processes, this is largely based on assumptions, which are partially based on various redposts I red over the years, and partially based on how I'd do it conceptually.


Due to the size of the player base, Riot wants to leave as much as possible to the automated process, since that saves a lot of time, money and effort. But since they're handling player accounts, they also want as little false positives as possible.

From the second condition it follows that when the automated process is uncertain what to do, it will instead of doing something snd it towards for manual review.
It follows from the first condition, that you want this to happen as rarely as possible.
Logically, that means you want to have the automated process to be as accurate (and thus certain in its actions) as you can achieve.

But here's the thing, you can't possibly know that the system will detect all kinds of toxicity, so the uncertainty in pardoning a case is always higher. It has to, at least occasionally, still trigger a manual review, no matter how certain it is in its verdict. Just to make sure it's not missing something.

That's where report filtering come in handy, since... well say somebody literally reports every single person they have ever played with and the system's sure their newest report was bogus, then you really don't need to check that report manually. Chances are it's just another false report. 
If somebody however only ever reports the worst of the worst, and their report didn't result in a punishment? That's something you might want to check, so if somebody like that reports somebody, the uncertainty of the system in pardoning will be higher.


Again, this is all highly based on how I'd do it... and I hardly have any expertise.
Still, might give you an idea how report filtering could help Riot.

Thank you, that actually does help me see it from the opposite perspective I started thinking from, and sounds like it's definitely at least part of the reasoning behind things being the way they are. It makes sense.

I still believe having players out there with a reduced weight report (deserved or not) could in turn allow punishable players to escape punishment. 

Having said that however, I can imagine and accept why the situation is handled as such afterall, so I can't really blame the policy being used in that way.
